description: From Medieval Latin incentīvus (“that strikes up or sets the tune”), from incinō (“to strike up”), from in- (“in, on”) + canō (“to sing”). The formation appears to have been influenced by incendō (“to set on fire”).

adjectives.description: incentive (comparative more incentive, superlative most incentive)

entries.meaning: Inciting; encouraging or moving; rousing to action; stimulating.
examples: Competency is of all other proportions the most incentive to industry.

entries.meaning: Serving to kindle or set on fire.
Something that motivates, rouses, or encourages.
examples: I have no incentive to do housework right now.

entries.meaning: A bonus or reward, often monetary, to work harder.
examples: Management offered the sales team a $500 incentive for each car sold.
